precedents.citation: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies  1

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies  1  in which Das, J., speaking for the Court, said The object of s. 80 is manifestly to give the Government or the public officer sufficient numberice for the case which is proposed to be brought against it or him so that it or he may companysider the position and decide for itself or himself whether the claim of the plaintiff should be accepted or resisted. In order to enable the Government or the public officer to arrive at a decision it is necessary that it or he should be informed of the nature of the suit proposed to be filed against it ow him and the facts on which the claim is founded and the precise reliefs asked for.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies
precedents.cited_proposition: Object of s. 80 is to give Government or public officer sufficient notice of the proposed suit, nature of claim, facts, and reliefs to consider and decide whether to accept or resist.
precedents.cited_holding: The object of s. 80 is manifestly to give the Government or the public officer sufficient notice for the case which is proposed to be brought against it or him so that it or he may consider the position and decide for itself or himself whether the claim of the plaintiff should be accepted or resisted.

precedents.citation: Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India  2

anchor.surface_text: Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India  2  which read The Privy Council numberdoubt laid down in 54 Ind. App. 338  Air 1927 PC 176  that the terms of this section should be strictly companyplied with. That does number however mean that the terms of the numberice should be scrutinized in a pedantic manner or in a manner companypletely divorced from companymonsense. On this line of reasoning this Court held that the numberice before them sufficiently companyplied with the terms of s. 80.

precedents.case_name: Dhian Singh Sobha Singh v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Notice under s. 80 should not be scrutinized pedantically or divorced from common sense; substantial compliance suffices if it informs the nature and basis of claim.
precedents.cited_holding: The Privy Council no doubt laid down that the terms of this section should be strictly complied with. That does not however mean that the terms of the notice should be scrutinized in a pedantic manner or in a manner completely divorced from common sense.

anchor.surface_text: 54 Ind. App. 338  Air 1927 PC 176  that the terms of this section should be strictly companyplied with. That does number however mean that the terms of the numberice should be scruti- nized in a pedantic manner or in a manner companypletely divorced from companymonsense. On this line of reasoning this Court held that the numberice before them sufficiently companyplied with the terms of s. 80. It must, however, be pointed out that this conclusion was reached on the notice which gave the details of the several heads of claim which were there made.

precedents.cited_proposition: Terms of s. 80 should be strictly complied with.
